}} An 'electric guitar' is a guitar that uses a pickup to convert the vibration
of its strings into electrical impulses. The most common guitar pickup uses the
principle of direct electromagnetic induction. The signal generated by an
electric guitar is too weak to drive a loudspeaker, so it is amplified before
sending it to a loudspeaker. Since the output of an electric guitar is an
electric signal, the signal may easily be altered using electronic circuits to
add "color" to the sound. Often the signal is modified using effects such as
reverb and distortion.

Invented in 1931, the electric guitar became a necessity as jazz musicians
sought to amplify their sound in the big band format. During the 1950s and
1960s, the electric guitar became the most important instrument in pop
music. , [http://books.google.com/books?id=0wkIlnNjDWcC&pg=PA793 Extract of
page 793] It has evolved into a stringed musical instrument that is
capable of a multitude of sounds and styles. It served as a major component in
the development of rock and roll and many other genres of music.
